characters: IN MEMORY OF NATALIE "ALICE" SHELDRAKE M.D.,
TURN THE GOD DAMNED WHEEL TO THE
CAPTAIN'S WIFE AND SHIP'S SURGEON OF THE

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS OVER
dialogues.text: Wind on the water.  Soaring gulls and sand pipers glide over the pilings and sagging bulkheads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I hadn't seen or spoken to Sheldrake in over thirty years, it seemed impossible that his heart was the thing that had finally failed him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHUCK GIEG, 49, thin, windswept and handsome, is behind the wheel.  He pulls down a narrow cobble stone street that leads to the wharf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never got close to him, nobody did.  But by the time we made Tampa, I was sure I knew who he was, that I understood what he saw, what nourished his soul and tested his faith...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck stares out across the harbor.  In the distance, the echoes of singing masts.  Shrouds and canvas softly ping. The small boats of Mystic tug restlessly at their moorings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had taken us to worship, where, what was for him, the holiest of holies.  And, for us too by the end...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck stands silently on the periphery of a gathering of people.  They surround a small building, a neighborhood clinic.  A worn gray stone, long in the earth, dedicates the structure.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGANTINE ALBATROSS
dialogues.text: Next to the stone a funeral urn.  A YOUNG MINISTER gropes for meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know Richard Sheldrake personally, but his many friends who knew and worked with him, wanted to make sure that he was returned home, here, to be remembered with his beloved wife... Chuck gazes out at the sleepy harbor, the minister's voic fading away.  The afternoon wind is coming up with the tide.  He quietly heads towards the water.  Drifting, drawn, lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though he had moved on with his life, now even for the years, to hear him eulogized by strangers, seemed strange.  He had been a hewner of stones, a pilot by the silent stars.  Like me, alone among many.  But most of all for us, the crew of the brigantine Albatross, he was always and would forever be... our Skipper. A SHIP'S BELL turns him around.  Ding ding.  Ding ding. beautiful three masted schooner steady on the water slips into port.  A picture out of another time, another place. It takes him away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A towering monolith, surrounded by tall oaks and sycamores.  The tower is immense.  A single ladder runs u to the top.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TOP
dialogues.text: Just above the tree tops, the view is spectacular.  CHUCK GIEG, 16, sits thin and unsteady.  Chuck's gaze is drawn upward -- to the building spring cumulus clouds.  Chuck's older brother WILL, 18, stout, self assured, pulls himsel to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna jump?  Or are you just having a last look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking that I never had a new pair of shoes till I was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no my fault I was born first. Besides, nobody ever sent me on an eight month vacation, so ease up on the sad sack stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a vacation, it's private school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was your dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why he's sending me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it looks good. Chuck looks out, yearning.  Will considers him, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just not like you.  Ya know? I'm never going to go to Yale.  I'm never going to be "William".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody says you have to be like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't give him enough credit Chas. Chuck takes a last look at the building clouds.  The sky rumbles.  Distant thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maple street, USA, tree lined and quaint.  The Gieg home is a modest two story house with a covered porch.  The family station wagon is poised for departure.  CHARLES, 45, a generally serious man broods as MIDDY, their mother 40, soft and thoughtful, exits the house.  Chuck and Will appear from the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ticked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You plan on making this plane or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take any wooden nickels Kemosabe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't. Will shoves out a hand at Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lighten up will ya. Chuck hugs him anyway and walks to the passenger side. Charles tosses him the keys, like he's doing him a big favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck sits in the drivers seat.  Middy is in the back. Charles slams the trunk and gets in.  Before Chuck turns the ignition...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just take it easy.  We're not going to a fire. Chuck reacts.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Will watches as the car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: The Giegs drive in silence.  Middy reads from a brochure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, did you know that the Albatross was captured by the Germans during World War II?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says she was originally Schooner rigged, but Captain Sheldrake turned her into a brigantine.  I think square rigs look so much more romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appearances aren't everything.  Keep your mind on the road. Chuck pulls over to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Chuck hands him the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel like driving.  Okay? Charles regards him oddly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The National Airlines Boeing 707 is bigger than anything Chuck has ever seen.  Passengers begin boarding.  Charles stands away, detached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have your ticket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I just better go. Middy hugs her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye Mom.  I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you will. Chuck faces his dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make us proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Charles extends his hand.  They shake.  Then Chuck hurrie away into the crowd.  Charles and Middy watch until he is out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck settles into his seat next to the window.  He watches as the world slips away beneath the wings of the 707.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another world.  Chuck stands in line at the customs booth He cranes his neck to see the brilliant blue water and coral reefs beyond the runway. Three other boys are ahead of him in line.  The CUSTOMS AGENTS go through every piece of luggage.  TOD JOHNSTONE, 16, thin and blonde, is in a heated argument with one of the agents about his spear gun. RICK MARCH, 17, wise-cracking and confident, shakes his head, smiling.  He spots Chuck, moves through the line an shoves out a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albatross?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick March.  Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gieg, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, meet us out front when you're through.  If they try to take anything away from you like Johnny Quest up there, just make a list and we'll have 'em send it down to the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever. One of the agent starts pulling things out of Rick's duffel bag.  He finds a dive knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey!!  That's my stuff!!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The car whizzes through the narrow streets of Bermuda. CALYPSO MUSIC sings from the radio.  The streets are line with small coral houses and exotic palms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are jammed inside with their things.  In additio to Chuck, Rick and Tod, is CHARLIE STRATTON, also sixteen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Ricky boy, spear gun or no, it's sweet to be back in the world of rum and honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta admit I never thought you'd be back after the great "Bowsprit Affair".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Skipper had a meeting of the minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warming a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the "Bowsprit Affair"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Romeo here was on harbor watch and managed to sweet talk one of the local girls to have a go in the bowsprit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just any 'local' girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'local' mayor's 'local' daughter. Tod smiles, reminiscing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing is, the net in the basket isn't very comfortable, so Tod-o wraps them up in the jib.  After the deed was done...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says they did the deed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, we did the deed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the "alleged" deed was done, they fell asleep.  Big Daddy Lawford comes on deck at four bells and hears Casanova sawing logs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I needed the rest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets the whole crew on deck, gets us on the halyard, and orders the old "heave ho...".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up goes the jib and out roll Tod-o and the mayor's daughter, naked as pilot whales...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who was more surprised, you or Big Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I think it was her father. At the top of a hill, the harbor comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well gentlemen, there she is. The cab stops.  Besides many colorful fishing boats, is the ALBATROSS.  At ninety-two feet, she dwarfs everything in the harbor.  Her white hull glows like ivory and her twin masts and yard arms tower above her deck. Breathtaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home sweet hell on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys pile out of the taxi.  What seemed like a pristine ship from the hill looks like a rust bucket up close.  The white paint is streaked and barnacles cover the hull.  Looks of disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to it? A voice from behind turns Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cleans up.  We'll have her ship shape before we shove off. This is BILL BUTLER, 15, removed, the youngest of the cre and... first mate.  Bill gives Chuck a friendly slap on the back and climbs aboard.  He is greeted by a Viking giant of a man, LAWFORD, 37, and bearded, the ship's English professor. Puffing on a huge Havana cigar, he stares coolly down at Tod and the others.  He speaks with the voice of Moses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That this same child of honor and renown, This gallant Hotspur, this all praised knight, And your unthought-of Harry chance to meet. For every honor sitting on his helm, Would they were multitudes, and on my head.  My shames redoubled!  For the time will come... Chuck feels something and looks up where he meets the intense stare of a man standing between the deck cabins. Their eyes lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That I shall make this northern youth exchange, his glorious deeds for my indignities." Then, the man is gone.  Haunting.  Only Chuck has seen him.  Tod smiles back at Lawford impishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be addressing me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry the IV part I Act I Scene ii. I suggest you read it. Lawford sneers and walks away.  It's all a show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means Shakespeare.  B-o-r-i-n-g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means if he catches anybody basket-napping on watch this passage, he's gonna use their lizard for 'cuda' bait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's a hell of a how-do-you- do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop your gear, go below and pick yourself some bunks. Chuck and the others climb aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck makes his way down the companionway into the main cabin.  Other crew members are already unpacking. The sleeping arrangement is Pullman-style with two rows o bunks on each side of the cabin.  In the middle of the room is a gimbaled table.  This is where the crew will ea and study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up.  This is Chuck Gieg. Among the crew -- feature ROBIN WEATHERS, 16, a cherub with soft puffy cheeks and TERRY LAPCHICK, 17, skinny and rodent-like. Robin approaches with a hand extended.  He carries a 8x10 photo of a young man in a football uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Robin. Chuck regards the photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my brother.  He's dead. Apprehensively Chuck shakes and retreats to a lower bunk. Robin tacks up the picture above his bunk.  Terry unpacks in front of one of the lower berths. A loud "THUD!" turns everyone around.  A duffel bag lies at the bottom of the companionway.  A large imposing figure climbs into the cabin. This is JOHN GOODALL, 17, over six feet, big and broad. His hair is slicked back "Dean" style and wears a full day's growth of bread on his face.  Compared to the others, he looks all man.  Everybody clears from his path He stops in front of the lower, center bunk (Terry's bunk and drops his bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably didn't notice, but this bunk has been taken. John just glares at him, then dumps all of Terry's things onto the blanket on the bunk, gathers it up and tosses it into the remaining upper berth.  Terry watches, intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody gotta problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. John climbs into his bunk and closes his eyes.  Bill enters, followed by several adults. DR. ALICE SHELDRAKE, 30, smart, attractive and tough, is ship's surgeon and Skipper's wife.  Lawford appears with GEORGE PASCAL, 30's from Brazil, dark, and fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, listen up.  This is Dr. Alice Sheldrake. The guys stumble over only half listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ship's surgeon.  I'm in charge of aches, pains, biology, math and science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Pascal here is ship's cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to keep all your fingers, stay the hell out of my galley unless you're invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of you already know Mr. Lawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been charged with the dubious task of insuring your literary education. Lawford puts a hand on Bill's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Butler is your first mate.  But don't let his size fool you. Bill gives a half reluctant wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when the hell do we get to meet El Capitan? Snickering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's getting his wooden leg waxed. Laughter.  A sound stops the laughter.  Almost on cue, th sound of slow methodical footsteps, pace the deck above them.  Then a shadow falls across the skylight, blocking the light.  Ominous.  They all notice and look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mysterious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll meet him.  Soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn glows orange in the skylights above the cabin.  The only sound is the heavy, even breathing of slumber. Suddenly, a booming voice rumbles down the companionway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arise, Arise, Arise... Chuck wakes, disoriented.  Terry bolts upright and hits his head on the low ceiling.  Ouch. Tod, Rick and Charlie are up instantly.  Lawford's voice echoes through the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exultation is the going/ Of an inland soul to sea/ Past the houses/ Past the headlands/ Into deep Eternity/ Bred as we, among the mountains/ Can the sailor understand/ the divine intoxication/ of the first league out from land? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I suppose we'll answer that question soon enough gentlemen. Soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What question? Chuck tries to assimilate Lawford's words.  Robin swings his feet over the side of his bunk with a tortured look. John rolls over and pulls his pillow over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (foggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's an air raid. In crisply pressed shorts and shirt, Bill Butler steps through the aft bulkhead.  He raises a bowswain's  whistl and blows.  OOOWWWEEEEOOO!!!!  Chuck and Robin grab their ears.  It's a nightmare.  Terry jumps and hits his head again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll out sailors!  All hands on deck!  Sixty seconds.  Sixty seconds. He blows the whistle again.  This time it brings even Joh to his feet, staring down at Bill in a blind rage.  Bill looks up and casually notices him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta problem Goodall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You blow that thing again I'll shove it so far up your ass, you're gonna need dental floss to get it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get on deck. Bill turns and disappears topside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has barely cracked the horizon as the crew staggers onto the deck, shirtless and shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Line up!  Single file.  Single file. The crew lines up.  John is the last one through the hatc and he lets us know his boundaries are being pressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody swims. The boys are aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think people, just go!  Go, Go, Go, Go, Go!!!  Swim you win, stay you pay!! Rick is the first one through the gunnel door, followed b Tod and Charlie.  They howl and scream as they hit the water.  The rest follow like lemmings.  But John stands defiantly with his arms folded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what's the problem, Goodall? Everybody swims. The crew are piling back on deck.  George stands in the open galley door.  The smell of fresh bacon is intoxicating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will if you wanna eat.  Right George? George nods, wielding a butchers knife.  The crew stand shivering, waiting on John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna swim for your breakfast? Bill gives John a long look then strips to his shorts, swings into the rigging and climbs up to the first yard arm.  He looks down at the water some twenty-five feet below.  It's a long way.  Robin turns away. Lawford booms in a voice that echoes across the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Down, down beneath the deep, That oft in triumph bore him, He sleeps a sound and peaceful sleep, With the salt waves dashing over him." -- Lord Byron gentlemen. With that Bill leaps and hits the water with a huge KERSPLASH!  He swims to the boarding ladder, pulls himsel up and gets in John's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody swims.  Now, I've been in twice.  So I guess I'll be eating your breakfast too. John considers him, then strips off his shirt.  But instead of walking over to the gunnel door, he jumps into the ratlines, climbs to the foretop and looks down. He manages a thin smile then climbs to the second set of ratlines past the third yard and continues to the top yar arm -- the topgallant.  It's a pissing contest and everybody knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got five bucks says he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got five that says he doesn't live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a dollar of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy! Robin refuses to watch.  The others share a look. John makes his way along the foot ropes and stands at the end of the yard.  He tosses a look towards Bill but with no way to back down, he launches into the air.  Everyone gasps as he thunders through the air in a broad swan dive Falling, falling, falling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't watch this. John hits the water like a bullet.  The crew run to the side waiting for him to come up.  Nothing.  Finally, he breaks the surface.  Easy.  He climbs up waiting, somehow to claim victory. Suddenly, they all feel it.  A presence.  He has appeared silently on top of the Chart House, like a phantom gazing down at them, back lit by the sun the boys must squint to see him. RICHARD SHELDRAKE, (SKIPPER), ageless and windswept, casually reaches up to a block and tackle with one arm an glides to the deck.  He is powerfully built and bronzed from the sea and sun.  He carriers the burden of command like a cross.  Soft-spoken and remote, he is a man to be reckoned with.  The crew know they are in the presence of someone larger than life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skipper on deck! The crew line up clumsily.  Skipper has a gaze that blaze right through them. He looks out to sea.  Searching, ominous.  He waits until the silence is filled with everyone's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's out there?  Wind and wave and rain.  Endless glassy pools that'll hold a sailing ship for weeks and then spit her out into the eye of the kind of hurricane.  A blow that could knock the bridge off a battleship.  Reefs and rocks and sandbars that'll tear the belly from her and enough fog and night to hide it all. He spits into the water.  The crew sheepishly throw glances to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So look out there... and explain to me why any man in possession of any sense at all, would take on the sea with sail? Skipper turns his gaze back to the boys.  There is a fire in his eyes.  Nobody dare answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there's something else out there.  It beckons in the wind and sings in the shrouds.  Voices. Whispering... His ear to the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're voices of men.  Calling.  Men you don't even know.  Men you can't even imagine.  It's a seed, a wish, that part of you and I that aches to be alive, that was banished by everything we've ever been taught or told.  It's a part of us that can only be found on mountain tops and deserts, in the deepest caverns, smoking battle fields and... across oceans. He turns back to the sea, dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out there, is where it all waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was everything I had expected, part Ahab part Queeg and even Bligh. He spoke in whispers and answered all queries with efficiency and directness.  He had gone to sea for the first time at fifteen, the same age as Bill Butler.  And as he looked upon us that first day it must have been as though he were staring into a mirror. Skipper manages a sobering look and climbs on top of the chart house.  He pats a small brass sign that is welded t the main mast and reads the inscription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Where we go one, we go all." With that, he disappears below.  Nobody moves.  This is exactly the kind of man you want around when the shit hit the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This -- is gonna be a long eight months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys devour a hearty breakfast.  Tod is the 'galley slave' and fills glasses with orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chow down boys.  The milk and eggs are the first things to go once we put out. John enters balancing two plates heaped with food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know we gotta dumbwaiter for that. John looks over to the dumbwaiter mounted in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that one.  Tod-o here. The guys groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Har, har, har... John approaches the full table, glaring down at Terry who doesn't notice him.  Finally he looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm done.  I'm finished... He scrambles to get up and clear his plate.  John sits down without a word.  The others notice the two plates of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry, Goodall? He just grunts and starts eating.  Robin watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you jump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I felt like it. (sharp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as soon as you grow some balls, let me know. Robin bristles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.  It was a stupid stunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me. John grabs Charlie by his private parts and hoists him into the air.  Charlie gasps, the air sucked from his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever call me stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, he didn't mean anything. John shoves Robin to the floor with his free arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you girls something.  I do what I wanna do.  When I wanna do it.  And I don't give a shit what old Ahab up there thinks either. Any questions? John releases Charlie who crumples to the floor.  John resumes eating. Bill enters and reads the duty roster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here's the duty.  Gieg, Weathers, Lapchick, Schucart: scrape and paint.  Corry and Stricklin have the brass.  Robinson, you're the Galley slave.  March you're on chain gang with Barnes. Johnston, solo on bilge detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butler, what'd I ever do to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came back, Tod.  You came back. John continues to eat.  When he realizes his name hasn't been called, he looks up to meet Bill's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pissed, John tries to figure out the head.  Pumps going in, pumps going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were all thirteen individuals. We'd arrived the sum total of our limited experiences and the result of our parents' best, if not narrow, expectations... John pulls back on the lever, belching "water de le toilet" all over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck sits in a bowswain's chair over the side, with a paint roller in his hand.  The rust-streaked hull is bein transformed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Some of us were there for discipline, some for escape.  But I could see a small piece of myself in all of them and though I fought the notion, for me, I knew now, this would be home. A RADIO crackles in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "President Eisenhower today acknowledged that a secret American spy plane was in fact shot down over the Soviet Union.  The pilot has been confirmed as Francis Gary Powers..." Robin, Terry and Mike, are on the deck within earshot of Chuck with chisels and wire brushes chipping away at the rust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why couldn't it have been a wooden boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steel boats don't leak. Mike lights up a cigarette.  Robin notices.  Marlboro's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, can I have one? Mike sizes up Robin for a moment then tosses him the pack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks daddy-o. Robin lights up, grimacing with the first drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't brush too hard.  Looks to me like the only thing holding this bucket together is the rust. A voice booms up from the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahoy there. They turn.  Standing on the dock is FRANCIS BOUTILLIER, self important and overbearing, with his son, PHILIP, who looks as if this whole ordeal is some kind of punishment. Skipper appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. Francis boards without being invited.  Philip follows in his shadow.  He scrutinizes the condition of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albatross?  Doesn't inspire a lot of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, on the contrary, the Albatross is considered a very good omen.  It is said they embody the spirits of sailors passed on.  It's very bad luck if you kill one.  And dolphins too. The boys chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Francis Boutillier.  This is my son, Philip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Francis looks the Skipper over, reading him, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a day late.  We keep a schedule aboard ship.  Lives depend on it. (to Philip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Philip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. Skipper's directness bugs Francis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your cable said you wouldn't be putting out until mid-October.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, there's a lot to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indentured servitude is not what my son had in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a working ship.  Promptness is not a luxury, it's a necessity, as is the work to maintain her.  Had we been ready, I can assure you we would have sailed. Something in this exchange turns the tone of conversation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I would have expected compensation for my time and expense coming all the way down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happily, it all worked out... This time. (to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, take Philip below and help him find a bunk. Phil follows Bill down the companionway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be frank with you.  This was his mother's idea.  A romp through the Caribbean on a sailboat sounds more like a vacation than an education if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be more than that, I can promise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take good care of my son. There is threat in his tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do our best.  You're welcome to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a big boy. Francis leaves the boat.  Skipper and the crew watch as h climbs into his waiting embassy limousine and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was neighborly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't get to be Under Secretary of the Air Force by being neighborly. Lawford shakes his head.  Bill comes up through the companionway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone aboard young Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go sailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Albatross is under full power.  There is a sense of excitement and anticipation.  Charlie, Rick, Robin, and Lawford are on the halyard for the mainsail.  Skipper is at the helm with Alice and Bill nearby.  Skipper calls over to Chuck who stands alone at the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over here and take the wheel. Chuck's eyes light up as he walks over and takes the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold her steady into the wind. Southwest by west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentleman, when you hear an order, sing out.  I want to know that you've heard and understand. (quietly to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise the mainsail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise the main! Lawford and his group bellow out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise the main!! Lawford coaches the boys, sending two scurrying on top th chart house to loosen the stops which hold the heavy furled canvas to the main boom.  He guides another to the midships pinrail where the main halyard, which raises the huge sail, is made fast to a belaying pin.  He loosens th halyard and hands it to Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a turn under the pin and lead it out to the others.  You guys in the rear take up the slack.  Heave together now... In a beautiful tenor voice, Bill begins to croon a sea chanty, an old whaling song with an Irish lilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When the sun came up there was whisky in the cup..." The more experienced boys echo the line and pull to the beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When the sun came up there was whisky in the cup..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on the rest of you, sing!  Belt it out like men!! The newer guys like Chuck, John, Robin and Terry look at each other like this is the queerest thing they have ever heard of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Not one of us was a sober..." The boys return the verse half heartedly.  Lawford ties off his line and stares them down.  Skipper notices that the work has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong Mr. Lawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems we're short on singers. Skipper walks amid ship and addresses the crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone sings aboard a wind jammer gentlemen.  It lets everyone know you're in sync.  It shows unity, that all thoughts are one.  A crew that sings together stays together. Besides, I like it.  So, pipe up and be sailors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody swims, everybody sings... What's next?  Tap dancing? Lawford and Rick leap up onto the line pulling it down with their body weight.  They sing out the chorus.  The crew returns the song, somewhat reluctantly as the great mainsail starts to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tie it off!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outer Jib!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outta what? Coached by Tod, another group in the bow, awkwardly hoist the jib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll bear off to port and run down wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lawford, stand by to ease the mainsheet.  Rick, get on the jib sheet.  George, John, Philip, Tim and Dick go aloft to unstop the forecourse.  George will show you what to do.  Tod, show your men the forward pinrail and stand ready on the buntlines and clewlines. Forecourse first... work upward. The newcomers watch Bill with new-found respect.  George, John and the others climb to the forecourse, and out onto the footropes.  It's unsteady work and there's confusion everywhere.  But through it all, they continue to sing. Lawford moves to the mainsheet on the port side while the others move into their positions.  When Bill sees the yardarm crew is in place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unstop the squares!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unstop the squares!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chuck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall off to port.  Ease her around to a heading of northeast.  Sing out when you're there. As the tops are released, the giant forecourse drapes int a scalloped pattern.  As the bow falls off the wind the snapping main and jib billow.  Stiffening to the wind, th ship heels and surges forward. Before her awakening power, everyone changes their stance and grabs for a handhold.  Lawford slowly pays out the mainsheet while the forecourse crew move up the ratlines releasing the stops on the other squaresails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... Northeast... sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up boy! Chuck jumps, startled.  He self-consciously calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Northeast sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfurl the squares! Tod's group first uncleats the clewlines and buntlines an the great squaresail drops and billows to fullness sendin a shudder through the rig.  The bow's wake sizzles with the added surge.  As each of the squares fall, Alice and Lawford move to their sheets, setting each sail's position. Chuck looks up, amazed at the sheer magnitude and beauty of the canvas that the Albatross carries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise the inner jib!  Raise the forestaysail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the tell-tales Chuck.  If we jibe now we'll have a lot of people in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All stop on the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All stop on the engine! Bill rotates the telegraph handle back and forth and move it to the stop position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behold gentlemen.  The power of the wind! As the sails billow the Albatross seems transformed. Everyone stops and looks up.  The vessel heels and with a powerful surge, launches into the waves.  White foam splashes over the bowsprit as the hull thunders through the water.  Chuck's face is full of wonder.  It is a magical moment.  Then the crew begins to cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we lose anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Albatross under full sail is the handsome, powerful image of another time.  And yet, here she is.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: Each of the boys is awed by the majesty of this moment. Music builds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chart us a course for the windward side. Alice considers his request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That low passed through last night. May be a little bumpy out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time these boys saw some real blue water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bow of the Albatross explodes through the top of a fifteen foot swell.  The sky is clear but the wind is fierce.  In spite of the seas the ship is trimmed and sailing well. The crew has never seen mountains of water like this. Disaster seems imminent.  Bill has assembled them in fron of the wheel house.  They are all holding on for dear life.  Even John seems shaken.  Skipper magically stands effortlessly before them on the rolling deck.  He remains perfectly dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... now that I have your undivided attention... I'd like to take this opportunity to make a few points...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy is certifiable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicidal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing is I don't like people talking when I'm talking so the two of you, shut up. Caught, Terry and Phil button up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second, the next one of you who doesn't jump like a bunny when Mr. Butler gives an order is gonna spend the rest of this trip scrubbing bilges.  He's a better sailor today than any ten of you will be when this is all over. Skipper directs the next comment directly at John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I catch anybody, ever, jumping off a yard arm again I will personally break what bones are left and send you home in a wheel chair. A wave explodes over the bow.  A wall of water crashes over the deck knocking down several of the boys.  Terry can't take it anymore and explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna die!!!  We're all gonna die! He lunges at Skipper but Lawford one arms him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent point.  As you might have noticed, being out here pretty much puts you in the moment.  If you panic, if you lose your head, you die.  Maybe you take your mates with you.  How'd you like to have to bet on Terry here getting us home today? Each one of you is responsible for the rest.  "Where we go one, we go all".  If your buddy is asleep at the switch we're all fish food. He's making his point which is lost on no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship beneath you is not a toy and sailing is not a game.  The Albatross will take us far gentlemen, but she demands constant attention.  Respect her, and we'll do fine.  Oh, and one more thing. There is nothing that goes on, on this boat that I don't know about. She speaks to me in the night.  So don't test me.  Not even a little. Skipper walks over and puts an arm around Terry who is fighting sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like experience to put things in perspective.  Huh son? (to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawford addresses some of the crew.  Chuck, Robin and Joh are among them.  John glares at Lawford.  The guys giggle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a satisfactory answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, save it for somebody else will ya.  This ancient shit doesn't have anything to do with me. Lawford pauses for a moment and then explodes theatrically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit?!!! He slams a text book into John's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read for me please the words of Mr. Keats at the bottom of the page. John stares back, simmering.  Robin interrupts the potential confrontation and reaches for the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll read it.  I mean I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up donut. John pushes Robin's hands away and studies the page for a moment.  He begins reading but struggles with the cadence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much have I traveled in realms of gold/ And many goodly states and kingdoms seen/ Round many western islands have I been/ Which bards in fealty to Apollo hold/ Oft of one wide expanse had I been told/ That deep-browed Homer ruled as his demesne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what he is talking about here? Blank faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ranting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awe.  Humility.  He's telling you that he has traveled the seas as Homer did.  As Ulysses had before him as he tried to find his way home to Ithaca after the Trojan Wars. "That deep browed Homer"... He points to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant, seasoned, wise, of the mind; "... ruled as his demesne." He commands the voyage of the imagination, like a god. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is what one of the greatest literary minds of modern times, Mr. Boutillier, has to say about Homer. He snatches the book back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think the Odyssey is dull?  I'll tell you something, it's about each one of you -- right now.  Doubt and expectation.  Friendship, community, self sacrifice and accountability. He holds up the text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't just a story!!  It's history made allegory.  It is a philosophical handbook for life!  It holds the secret of this very voyage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it... the secret? Lawford breaks into a huge belly laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were only that simple, my young friend.  Read on, gentlemen. Read on.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Aerial shot.  The Albatross is under full sail leaving Bermuda for the last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so it was the Albatross that took to the open sea with the wind in her snapping canvas and a bone of white foam in her teeth... In each of us were feelings of anticipation and hesitation for the man at the wheel and of the unfamiliar world he was leading us into. She crashes through the surf -- driving, majestic music, building.

dialogues.speaker: DECK
dialogues.text: The crew hauls in the line, raising the mainsail.  Chuck struggles to coil the rope as fast as it is coming in.

dialogues.speaker: ALOFT
dialogues.text: The crew take turns racing up the ratlines into the rigging.

dialogues.speaker: BOWSPRIT NET
dialogues.text: The crew pull down the jib trying to furl it.  Most of th sail ends up dragging in the water.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: The squaresails are dropped simultaneously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White foam boils from the bow of the Albatross as she crashes through the waves.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE WHEEL
dialogues.text: Alice smiles and puts her arms around Skipper's waist. It's coming together.

dialogues.speaker: FORETOP
dialogues.text: Skipper stands at the rail, looking out.  The seas are up and the masts are pitching widely from side to side. Chuck is high above the deck in the footropes, wrestling with one of the squaresails.  The pitching mast catches him by surprise and he slips.  He tumbles down, tangled i the lines.  A rope wraps around his neck, choking him. Robin looks up and sees him hanging helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill!!  Skipper!! Robin freezes.  Skipper leaps into the rigging like a spider and, in a few seconds, wrestles Chuck free and carries him down to the deck.  Chuck coughs, catching his breath.  The color is gone from Skipper's face.  This was a close call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my fault.  I slipped. Alice examines Chuck, making sure he's okay.  Skipper turns to Robin, who is shaken.  He never raises his voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you go up there? Robin stands silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up. Still nothing from Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's afraid to climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (to Robin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true? Robin looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wasn't I made aware of this Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your job to know.  If something goes wrong up there, the other eighteen people aboard can't be wondering if he's gonna do his job or not. Skipper returns his gaze to Robin, measuring him. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swing up, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trembling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up you go.  Right now. Robin reluctantly pulls himself up onto the first rung, then the second.  He stops and steals a peek up.  The mas is swaying.  He freezes, his lip starts to tremble.  All eyes are on him.  Phil chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then keep your mouth shut. Phil backs off, stunned.  Robin can't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Robin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry won't cut it. Robin holds on frozen.  Skipper turns to the crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Survival means discipline and assimilation.  There are no special cases here. (to Robin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, get going.  Get up there. Humiliated, a tear slips down his face.  Excruciating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you blubbering about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Skipper jumps onto the backside of the ratlines.  His fac is but inches from Robin's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hand in front of the other son. We'll do it together. Robin reaches for the next rung.  He looks down.  Skipper growls at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look down.  Look in my eyes! Climb!  We'll do it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You climb damn it, or so help me I'll haul you to the foretop by your diaper and leave you there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaauuuhhh!!! Skipper gets right in his face and snarls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hating this?!  Are you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you, you son of a bitch!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Hate the fear inside of you! Climb like a man mister!  Hate it! Hate it away.  Hate your way up one more rung!!  Do it right now!! With every ounce of strength, Robin reaches for one more rung screaming as he reaches.  Skipper climbs and screams with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auuuggghhh!!!! Robin clutches the rung with a death grip.  Then, he look down.  His bladder releases.  Hot urine runs down his leg and splashes, steaming, onto the deck.  The crew is horrified.  Robin weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, god... Skipper backs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hate yourself.  Hate your weakness.  All right.  Get down. Robin climbs to the deck and falls in with the others, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only gonna say this one time. I'm not here to wipe noses and asses.  I'm not your mother.  Trust funds and blue blazers don't get you a thing out here.  You wanna act like babies, then get off my boat. Stunned, the crew is speechless.  Chuck instinctively goe to help Robin.  Skipper snaps like a turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chuck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can take care of himself. (to others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any other 'phobias' I need to know about? Skipper fires a look towards Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent.  Bill, find Mr. Weathers a position to suit his condition. Skipper turns and then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember something, sooner or later... we all have to face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face what? The question hangs in the air like a cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chart house is the communication and navigation cente for the boat.  It also serves as the officers dining room Skipper, Alice, Lawford, George, and Bill Butler sit around the small table sipping coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're awfully quiet tonight. The group remains silent.  Lawford and George exchange a glance.  Skipper catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something on your mind, George? George looks up and wipes his mouth with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you were too hard on Weathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I do. Skipper nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to know what I'm working with; what their boundaries are. Their lives depend on it, and for that matter so does yours.  We've got to bring them together.  Make them a crew.  We're as strong as our weakest link and I don't want to find that out the hard way.  So, I will challenge them and they will come together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the best thing about being a Skipper is the worst thing.  It's all my responsibility.  So I'll tell you what George, you stay off of my bridge, and I'll stay out of your galley.  We'll get along that way. Everyone's quiet, but clear.  Skipper and Alice exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking bastard. Lawford lets out a belly laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen him snatch the tail of the tempest and stuff it, screaming, into a bottle.  The bilges are full of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been beyond the reach.  To the edge of the abyss and back.  He'll do well by us all George.  He's a real salt.  There's no malice in him and there's nothing more dear to him than his boys.  So sleep well my friend. Lawford seductively produces a pair of Havana cigars, passes one to George and winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin leans over the sink elbow deep in dishwater watchin through the cabin window, as the sun slips below the horizon.  Chuck stands in the doorway with a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I appreciate, you know, the concern and all, but like he said, I can take care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just brought you something to eat. Robin turns and notices the plate of food and nods.  They stand silently.  It's awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I got you into this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm used to spending a lot of time alone.  I guess that's what I thought it would be out here.  But, it's not is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I left you hanging up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.  Really.  I'm just sorry you got chewed out. Robin nods.  They both stare out at the rising moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother and I used to climb to the top of this old beech tree in the back yard and watch the moon come up just like this.  My parents would fight all the time so we'd sneak out there where we couldn't hear 'em and recite scenes from our favorite movies. Robin grows quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you believe I miss it?  The middle of paradise and I'm homesick. Chuck smiles and puts a hand on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't worry.  It'll all be there when we get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is dark and a storm is building and the boat roll and pitches.  Chuck sees Terry heaving over the side. John and Tod hear the sound and turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on man.  Show a little backbone! (to Tod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that?! Tod is fixated on Terry.  Suddenly, without warning, he breaks for the rail and lets fly. Phil and Charlie are next.  Chris climbs through the companionway but doesn't make it to the side.  Spontaneou regurgitation.  Bill and Lawford jump up onto the wheel housing to avoid being sprayed.  Suddenly everyone is heaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna have nobody left up here to crew.  Better let Skipper know. Bill nods and disappears.  John joins Chuck watching the events around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Gieg, I'm glad to see I'm not the only guy on this boat that can take a little rock'n roll.  Bunch of wusses, I swear...! Chuck watches each of his shipmates.  Then, suddenly, out of nowhere -- Projectile vomit all over John.  He looks a Chuck, horrified, then he too, cuts loose over the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch!! Chuck looks at John, furious with himself, and begins to laugh.  But after a moment he starts to laugh too.  It's infectious, they crack each other up.  Then, in the middl of belly laughing, they simultaneously retch again over the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skipper sits at his desk with some charts spread out in front of him.  There's a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skipper, uh, the crew is pretty much doing group boot over the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's all part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got weather moving in from the west. Skipper looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's part of it, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skipper stands at the wheelhouse with Lawford, George and Bill, studying the horizon through binoculars.  Dark clouds.  Chuck watches Skipper.  Everyone, looking for a cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a... storm, Skipper? Skipper stays glued to the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you, um, say it's a big storm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it gets exciting out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barometer's dropping.  The first blow'll come from the south.  Might get interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we turn away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't run from the wind son. You trim your sails, face the music and let the chips fall.  Bill, let's close her up, dog, tight. Close on hatches and skylights slamming closed and cinche tight.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW DECKS
dialogues.text: Bulkhead doors are closed and cranked down tightly.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLEY
dialogues.text: Pots and pans crash around.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MAIN CABIN
dialogues.text: The cabin doors on the bookcase swing open and dump books on top of Alice.  She turns and looks at the mess, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furl the squares, reef the main, and bend on the storm jib, but keep it furled.  Drop everything but the inner jib.  I want everybody down before we get any lightning. Bill bolts forward with Lawford barking orders.  Most of the crew are still ill, but climb into the rigging and begin dropping sail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's it always happen at night? Skipper regards George, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George... I want hot food in everybody.  Get to it. George returns to the galley.  Alice joins Skipper at the wheelhouse handing him foul-weather gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. He slips on a yellow slicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor and tell Bill once she's dogged down I want everyone to break out their slickers and make sure their gear is stowed or we'll spend the next week sorting underwear. (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawford, Bill, Mike, John, and Phil will stand the watch.  Everyone else hit the racks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impulsively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not staying out here. Skipper fires off a look that frightens even Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's for sure.  Charlie, take his place. Phil goes below, a little ashamed.  The crew scatters. Chuck, still at the wheel, pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's all the same, I'd like to stay on deck. Skipper regards Chuck, who looks back with both fear and eagerness.  Suddenly he sees something in this kid.  Mayb himself.  He almost smiles.  Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark clouds blot out the sky and stars.  Thunder rumbles far away.  The seas have built but there's no wind... yet With no steerage, the ship is tossed. Tod hangs high above the heaving deck continuing to furl. The mast swings from side to side, but the air has gone dead calm.  Skipper looks up, anticipating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone out of the rigging NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody down!  ON THE DOUBLE!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DECK
dialogues.text: The crew in the rigging scamper down to the safety of the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, on the wheel with Chuck. Bill joins Chuck and takes hold of the wheel.  Then it hits. A wall of torrential rain drums the deck amid a tympany o thunder and flashing lightning.  The bow explodes through twelve foot swells.  This is what the Albatross was born to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all the crew can do to stay in their bunks.  Pots crash, books and personals go flying.  The guys are scared.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: The main and jib sheets tighten.  Skipper looks at Chuck and Bill.  It all comes down to moments like these and he loves it. Suddenly, there is a loud CRACK!  A violent flapping noise.  Skipper leaps to the port and looks forward.  Tod comes running back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We blew the inner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring it down and run up the storm jib.  We'll fix it later.  Stay out of reach of the blocks! Tod and Alice disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a twinkle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're in it now. Chuck studies him, frightened, but reassured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shredded jib and rigging whip violently in the wind. The block smashes into the gunnel rail, shattering it.  N one dares go near it.  For a moment, it seems to hang there seductively.  John, naive of its power, leaps for the rail and grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: NOOO
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the wind cracks the sail instantly hurling John high off the deck and over the side.  He holds on for dea life, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chuck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold her steady. Skipper bolts forward.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BOW
dialogues.text: Alice uncleats the jib halyard, leaving one turn on the pin and shoves it into Tod's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Release this when I tell you!! Skipper joins Tod as Alice scrambles along the deck and pulls herself into the bowsprit netting.  When the block and jib swing inboard, she grabs for the leach of the sai yelling...

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: As John is snapped inboard Alice leaps up, grabbing the sail, leaning out over the open water.  Waves explode through the netting.  As Tod releases the halyard, John falls to the deck, bruised, humbled, but alive.  Lawford and Skipper pull Alice from the bowsprit. Skipper looks her over.  Relieved.  No broken bones.  Goo work.  But then this is what he expects.  He respects her and now, everyone can see why.  He looks at John sprawled on the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ever you say Cap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get that storm jib up. Skipper gives Alice a private look, then returns to the stern where Chuck holds tightly onto the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm lasted sixteen hours and it set us all on equal footing.  It was the first time that we shared an episode on an even plane.  As we stood our watches we were equally out of control of our situation, regardless of our physical abilities or social backgrounds.  And though our real feelings lay hidden beneath bravado and defiance, we were no longer strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew is cleaning up.  Alice supervises repairs to the jib while others stow line, scrub the deck and chip paint Lawford paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what they say in the Navy don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Big Daddy? The more experienced crew members have heard this all before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If it moves, salute it.  If it doesn't move, pick it up.  If it's too big to pick up, paint it!" The boys mockingly salute Lawford as he walks by.  John stands before a porthole combing his Brylcreem hair into

dialogues.speaker: "D.A."
dialogues.text: Mike and Chris climb on deck with several large boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies, gentlemen and hermaphrodites, Mr. Corry and I are happy to announce the grand opening of Trans-Border Enterprises. They start opening the boxes.  One is a case of Coca Cola another is full of cigarettes and candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the creature comforts and vices you could possibly want, at home or abroad, available twenty- four hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a price, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've got "a broad" available I'll take her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you'd know what to do with one. The crew shakes their heads, mutter and check out the goods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got Marlboro's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absa-fuckin-lutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toss me a Cola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contraband's hard to come by out here son. John is still grooming at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Goodall, you got a date or something? John continues to comb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  With your mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooooooo. Phil slinks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also have a few rental items... Chris displays a Playboy magazine.  Everybody clamors to get a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a penalty for any material returned to the Trans-Border Library with sticky pages. John walks by, snatches the magazine and heads for his bunk flipping through the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you can't do that!! (to Chris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't do that!! John flops in a deck chair.  Chris shakes his head and starts closing up the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck sits alone, away from the others, reading.  On cue, half of the crew descend, dragging him kicking and screaming into the bowswain's chair, and over the side. The guys cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on you guys, this isn't funny! The seat spins, twists and swings from behind the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Chucky.  Show us a little grit. They lower the chair so it glides just above the surface. When the boat noses into a swell Chuck gets quite a ride. Once he has the hang of it, fear turns to elation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, who's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding?  He's a human chum line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No self respecting shark is gonna take a bite out of you. Chuck's hauled back in and Terry pushes his way to the front of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm next! Terry goes over the side.  Once he gets the hang of it, h gets into it.  He maneuvers the chair like a plane, forcing himself deep into the waves and then blasting bac to the surface.

dialogues.speaker: OFF THE PORT SIDE
dialogues.text: Robin is trolling.  The line takes a tremendous hit and Robin's reel screams.  Tod is at the wheel and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she blows!! Two hundred feet out something large and pissed has taken the bait.  The crew turn and look.  Skipper looks out at Terry still in the bowswain's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him in. Bill waves at Terry to come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in!!! Terry waves him off and disappears back under the waves. They can't pull him up while he's going under the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it now Bill. Terry pops up, pissed that they're reeling him back in. Suddenly the animal on the other end of Robin's line explodes out of the sea.  It's a six foot Thresher shark. Terry sees it too and freaks, suddenly thrashing and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out!!!  Get me out!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!!  It's a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shark. (to Robin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lose it son. George grabs a gaffing hook while Robin fights the rod, trying to bring in the big fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it coming. Robin battles the fish.  George clumsily tries to help. The crew make their way to the rear to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops. Charlie and Rick and the others heave to get Terry up. Finally he makes it.  Sprawling onto the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus!  Oh Jesus Christ!! The crew turn and cheer Robin on as he brings the shark alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must be two hundred pounds! Bring him in close and try to hold him steady. George leans out over the rail, trying to get the hook into a gill.  Several of the boys hold onto him as the fish flops around violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got him! Skipper comes down to inspect the catch.  The shark is longer than Terry is tall and thrashes in the the water, snapping and twisting.  Terry stands shaking, freaked. All of them are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn Terr, you're whiter than Sister Mary Anne's butt. The guys laugh nervously.  Terry just stares at the man eater, but it's infectious.  After a moment he's laughing too.  Skipper slaps him on the back with a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now you have something to write home about. More laughter.  Suddenly, Tom, who is lookout on the foretop, cries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land ho!!!  Land ho!!! Everyone turns around to look.  The guys at the stern let go of George and he nearly tumbles overboard.  In that instant, the shark slips off of the gaff, and disappears back into the sea.  Robin and George share a stunned look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more where that came from. Skipper returns to the wheelhouse with Alice.  Together they scan the horizon.  Clouds build over the land ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheated death again. He slips an arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of islanders have assembled to watch the crew approach in the long boats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck gazes across the strange landscape.  As the boats dock, the crew pile out and scatter.  Local children follow them wherever they go.  Chuck, Robin and John find themselves alone.  Most of the buildings are primitive. They wander over to a shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say?  Cokes?  I'm buying. CHUCK & JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck and Robin reappear, sipping cold Cokes.  Mike and Chris walk by across the street.  Robin speaks up loud enough for them to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right Chuck.  There's nothing quite as refreshing as a cold ten cent Coke that only costs ten cents! The three clink their bottles.  Mike and Chris slink away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crumbling fort overlooks the harbor.  Below, the Albatross floats like a pearl on the azure blue water. Large bronze muzzle-loading cannons still lie in their gunports, aimed at the sea, waiting for pirate ships that will never come. Each of the guys are sprawled on a cannon, taking in the Caribbean view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Skipper and Alice do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know... "It".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's like wondering if your mom and dad do it.  Who wants to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She isn't that old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean she looks pretty damn good in her all-together for being thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me donut.  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the dog watch, night after the storm, I look down into the skylight above Skipper's cabin and there she was, peelin' down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on man, what'd they look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Porkchop, you sound just like a guy who ain't never seen a pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen 'em.  I've seen 'em. They crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I walked in on my parents one time. It was only like eight o'clock and they were in bed and I thought that was kinda weird so I just walked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they get for not locking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm standing there and you could hear a pin drop.  No breathing or snoring... Suddenly it hits me that somethin' was goin' on that just stopped, really fast, like people are holding their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother says in this really low, but very awake kind of voice "What?" John and Robin crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said "Sorry, wrong room" and walked away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you shut the door at least? They bust up again.  Chuck glares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember. Robin sits up on his cannon and looks out, suddenly melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents don't do it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?  They might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause they're getting a divorce. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they sent me here.  My sister's at Tabor.  They just wanted us out of the house so they could get down to business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
